ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 1: the only pertinent reading was Harlow& Harrar's but many did not read it. It should be more mandatory. It will be a book on my professional shelf!Question 4 is difficult to answer. The TA was not great at his job, which caused many of us to feel like we were falling behind. It is the professor's job to teach us (which Ann tends to lack doing) but knowing this, the TA should have stepped up to fill her gaps. Since he did not the pace felt quick! This goes with Question 8: she would point to a plant and ask us to ID it but then walk away without giving an answer. If she were better she would confirm/correct our answers but since she doesn't do this then the TA should have.This all affects Question 11. It is a necessary class and I learned a lot, but I taught a lot of it to myself because the professor and TA fell short of teaching clearly and effectively

This material is crucial for all MFs.RE Field Trips: Really helpful when out in the woods and identifying trees. I think it could be even more useful in field trips to provide a 15 minute introduction into typical vegetative communities on the site prior to arriving for context. There were a couple of field trips that were not useful but were generally interesting - the Greeley Botanical Gardens/ Green Houses and the plant storage field trip on Yale campus were neat but not very closely related to material we would be tested on or is useful to know.The taxonomy/ dendrology book and field guide are great as references but were not incorporated in a systematic way into the course. I think that anywhere from 3-7 very small homework assignments to reinforce field learning prior to the final would have been really helpful.The slides are clearly pretty old and recycled from previous years. There were a bunch of questions on the final that we just did not go over in class at all.I think adding one more lecture in the beginning of the course to explain broad clade relationships would provide a nice framework for filing away information learned about trees

I really enjoyed this course. I wish it were designed a little differently because I think I could have learned even morefrom the course. I wish that each field trip would focus on learned a select set of trees or shrubs so that I could feel more confident in my identifying skills.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips and becoming more confident in my abilities to ID trees

The field trips were great way to learn tree identification. I thought the field trips and field practicums were well organized, especially given how tough it is to plan field trips around weather conditions. I also thought the exams were fair and covered a nice range of topics.
Field tripsEntirely practicalSpending time with Ann is always a pleasureThe trees to know excel file is amazing

Field trips and applied learning opportunities were the best part of this course. Being able to see plant features in person as you learn the taxonomy is a great approach and one that will ensure that this knowledge sticks with me beyond the term.
I loved getting the chance to be outside every Monday and get to know trees.

The field trips were fun, and it was a great chance to spend some time outside. I did learn most of the trees on the trees-to-know list, which will be extremely helpful in future class and professional work.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The professor's explanations and descriptions of what we're seeing. I understand that we jump right in to field trips because it could snow soon, but when she's telling us to "look at the buds" without ever having shown or described these buds we can't be expected to learn!Frequently there was no confirmation of what we were seeing, especially no reiteration later in lecture or on another day to give us context or a memory of what we had seen.
I can't think of any. I think the class was fantastic!
Please see above answer

The structure of learning trees is quite jumbled and would benefit from more organization / explanation. For instance, if each field trip could focus on one family, I think that the course could teach both plant identification and orders/families/etc simultaneously. As it's taught, the course feels a bit overwhelming.I could also see more frequent quizzes proving valuable over one big ID mid-term. For instance, having a quiz on the oaks, then the maples, then the birches would allow for more measured / meaningful studying compared with trying to memorize all the plants for the mid-term at the same time. I feel like I lost a lot of that information as soon as the mid-term was over.
A stronger link between lecture material and field trips is needed.
I wish at times that the course set-up would have allowed for even more learning.

The structure of the course needs to change. There were too many field trips--by the last trip, we knew most of the trees/shrubs. The lecture material needs to be spread out over the course of the semester since it is very dense and covers very specific information. I felt very unprepared for the final since the lecture material was covered at the very end of class. We also learned the trees in an unsystematic way. While the field trips helped, I learned most of the trees the week of the midterm by looking them up online or using field guides.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I think there could be an initial test on learning the scientific names of trees and shrubs with a follow-up midterm on identification. It was difficult to learn them both at the same time.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This class is essential to the MF curriculum! There actually needs to be a better and more intense Taxonomy/Dendrology course! This professorexpects us to remember lifestyle characteristics of plants from a rushed, superficial lecture rather than spending intense time on many important species so that we can really identify distinguishing characteristics and know why/where species grow! I cannot say that I have walked away with a strong knowledge of this! I plan to teach it to myself in my free time later...
This course was crucial to gaining credibility as a forester and confident spending time in the woods
The course will be invaluable for my work. Tree ID and natural history alike.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: MF requirement and I wanted to learn this topic even though I knew it would be incomplete
I took this course because I'm personally interested in the topic.
To learn how to identify trees and woody plants
To improve my field ID skills and understanding of the relationships between various trees.
I thought it was just to feel more confident in my ability to know trees and shrubs but I realized in the process that it will apply directly to my future work.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, but I had relatively low expectations.
Definitely!
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
I loved getting to spend time learning this material.
I did learn most of the trees of Southern New England, which again will be invaluable, but I could have learned so much more if the class was taught in a more structured way.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read Harlow& Harrar early, and get started early in teaching yourself the intricacies of all species! You won't regret it!!During field trips, stand right next to Ann and don't lose that position! Otherwise you won't get many answers/information
Don't try to cram for the exams. If you study the trees learned right after each field trip, you should be fine for the exams!

Do it!Ask Ann lots of questionsMake sure that the field trips are useful. Sometimes they get to a point where you are just walking in the woods randomly pointing at trees without much intention. When you ask Ann questions - it makes it all so much more worthwhile. She has a fountain of knowledge on taxonomy.
Take it and ask for more structure to the field trips.

If you want to learn tree identification for pure curiosity, this class is great. However, if you are looking to be a professional forester and need an intensive crash course, this is probably not the one for you.
